comment_text.dn24:1.1.2: This late sutta satirizes the failings of Sunakkhatta in a fashion so broad that it borders on slapstick. The town of Anupiya is mentioned only here.
comment_text.dn24:1.1.6: The Bhaggava clan was descended from the ancient sage Bhagu (Sanskrit Bhṛgu). They received the gift of fire conveyed by Mātariśvan the wind from the god Agni (eg. Rig Veda 1.60.1). In Pali they appear as potters (eg. MN 81:19.3, MN 140:1.3, SN 1.50:11.2, SN 2.24:12.2). Archaeologists refer to the strata around the Buddha’s time as the Northern Black Polished Ware culture on account of the distinctive highly glazed polish that was achieved on the pottery of the time. This, together with the production of iron, marked a significant advance in the mastery of fire. Thus potters were no mere humble craftsmen, but leading technological innovators.
comment_text.dn24:1.2.10: Sunakkhatta’s dismal spiritual career began when he met the Buddha in MN 105. In DN 6:5.3 we learn that, after being ordained three years, he spoke of his limited success in meditation. The current sutta and MN 12 deal with Sunakkhatta’s bitter criticisms of the Buddha shortly after his disrobal.
comment_text.dn24:1.3.6: A candidate for ordination is expected to go for refuge to the Buddha, and may be said to live dedicated (uddissa) to him (Kd 1:23.4.1). Moreover, a noble disciple is unable to dedicate themselves to another teacher (AN 1.276:1.1). But when the Buddha called candidates to go forth, he spoke of practice rather than personal devotion: “Come, monk. The Teaching is well-proclaimed. Practice the spiritual life to make a complete end of suffering.” (Kd 1:6.32.3)
comment_text.dn24:1.4.1: He makes a similar criticism at MN 12:3.8.
comment_text.dn24:1.7.1: There are at least eight spellings for this tribe, including thulu, bumu and khulu. Below we meet a member of the ruling clan of the tribe named korakhattiya. I propose that kora is “of Kuru” by way of secondary derivation; cp. Koravya as a regular name for the kings of Kuru. Thus korakhattiya is not a personal name, but rather “the aristocrat of Kuru”. The name of the city uttarakā means “northern”, and Kuru is indeed northern. Occam’s razor would urge us not to assume the existence of an otherwise unknown tribe on such a dubious term when it can be explained more parsimoniously as an ancient misspelling of Kuru. The Chinese at DA 15 (T 1, 67a15) has 白土 (“white clay”), which does not seem to clear it up.
comment_text.dn24:1.7.3: This practice is further described, along with the “cow vow”, at MN 57.
comment_text.dn24:1.7.18: Alasaka is otherwise unknown in early Pali. Sanskrit medical texts describe it as flatulent indigestion. This agrees with the subcommentary’s ajīraṇena āmarogena (“indigestion”). | In this sutta, the Buddha is depicted as making specific predictions about the future, whereas normally he does not and probably cannot. Rather, he makes conditional predictions that if such courses are pursued, such results will follow.
comment_text.dn24:1.7.19: The terrifying Kālakañjas are mentioned at DN 20:12.5.
comment_text.dn24:1.9.5: This whole passage is unprecedented in early Buddhism. If Sunakkhatta was indeed able to revive the dead with three punches, it would explain why he thought so little of the Buddha’s powers. But the ease with which this information is obtained contrasts with the elaborate failures of Pāyāsi (DN 23).
comment_text.dn24:1.11.3: In these practices we see some examples of the vows or observances (vata) that Buddha rejected as “grasping at precepts and observances”
comment_text.dn24:1.11.4: A diet of pure meat is still undertaken today by certain would-be gurus.
comment_text.dn24:1.11.5: Compare the “vow of restraint in the directions” in the Jain Tattvārthasūtra 7.1.
comment_text.dn24:1.12.5: Āsādimhase is middle aorist plural. Below Sunakkhatta again refers to himself in plural, but as usual I render with singular.
comment_text.dn24:1.15.2: The Burmese reading pāthikaputta means “son of a traveler”. However the commentary says Pāṭika (or Pāthika) was the name of his father.
comment_text.dn24:1.15.4: For ñāṇavādo (“one who speaks from knowledge”) see AN 9.38:3.3, AN 10.24:2.1, MN 26:15.7.
comment_text.dn24:2.7.3: Apadāna means “what has been left over, leavings, traces”.
comment_text.dn24:2.13.1: This kind of elaborate display is commonly depicted in late texts, but is not otherwise found in early Pali.
comment_text.dn24:2.14.2: Compare DN 1:1.36.3. The following passage is largely adapted from the Brahmajālasutta.
comment_text.dn24:2.16.3: Text has suññaṁ, but this appears to be a mistake, since the mansion is no longer “empty” as Brahmā is already there. Follow DN 1:2.4.3, which lacks suññaṁ.
comment_text.dn24:2.17.20: This statement is not explicitly phrased as a question, but the Mahāsaṅgīti edition inconsistently punctuates it as one. It makes more sense in context, especially as a response to the initial question: Kathaṁvihitakaṁ (“How do you describe …”) … Evaṁvihitakaṁ (“Is this how you describe …”).
comment_text.dn24:2.17.22: This is adopted from DN 1:2.2.1. These philosophers belong with the “partial eternalists”.

root_text.dn24:1.13.1: Atha kho, bhaggava, sunakkhatto licchaviputto yenāhaṁ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā maṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinnaṁ kho ahaṁ, bhaggava, sunakkhattaṁ licchaviputtaṁ etadavocaṁ:
root_text.dn24:1.13.4: tvampi nāma, moghapurisa, samaṇo sakyaputtiyo paṭijānissasī’ti?
root_text.dn24:1.13.5: ‘Nanu tvaṁ, sunakkhatta, acelaṁ kaḷāramaṭṭakaṁ upasaṅkamitvā pañhaṁ apucchi.
root_text.dn24:1.13.6: Tassa te acelo kaḷāramaṭṭako pañhaṁ puṭṭho na sampāyāsi.
root_text.dn24:1.13.10: Mā vata no ahosi dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāyā”’ti.
root_text.dn24:1.13.12: Kiṁ pana, bhante, bhagavā arahattassa maccharāyatī’ti?
root_text.dn24:1.13.14: api ca tuyhevetaṁ pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ uppannaṁ, taṁ pajaha.
root_text.dn24:1.13.15: Mā te ahosi dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāya.
root_text.dn24:1.13.16: Yaṁ kho panetaṁ, sunakkhatta, maññasi acelaṁ kaḷāramaṭṭakaṁ—
root_text.dn24:1.13.17: sādhurūpo ayaṁ samaṇoti, so nacirasseva parihito sānucāriko vicaranto odanakummāsaṁ bhuñjamāno sabbāneva vesāliyāni cetiyāni samatikkamitvā yasā nihīno kālaṁ karissatī’ti.
root_text.dn24:1.13.18: Atha kho, bhaggava, acelo kaḷāramaṭṭako nacirasseva parihito sānucāriko vicaranto odanakummāsaṁ bhuñjamāno sabbāneva vesāliyāni cetiyāni samatikkamitvā yasā nihīno kālamakāsi.
root_text.dn24:1.14.2: ‘acelo kira kaḷāramaṭṭako parihito sānucāriko vicaranto odanakummāsaṁ bhuñjamāno sabbāneva vesāliyāni cetiyāni samatikkamitvā yasā nihīno kālaṅkato’ti.
root_text.dn24:1.14.3: Atha kho, bhaggava, sunakkhatto licchaviputto yenāhaṁ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā maṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinnaṁ kho ahaṁ, bhaggava, sunakkhattaṁ licchaviputtaṁ etadavocaṁ:
root_text.dn24:1.14.5: yatheva te ahaṁ acelaṁ kaḷāramaṭṭakaṁ ārabbha byākāsiṁ, tatheva taṁ vipākaṁ, aññathā vā’ti?
root_text.dn24:1.14.6: ‘Yatheva me, bhante, bhagavā acelaṁ kaḷāramaṭṭakaṁ ārabbha byākāsi, tatheva taṁ vipākaṁ, no aññathā’ti.
root_text.dn24:1.14.8: yadi evaṁ sante kataṁ vā hoti uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṁ akataṁ vā’ti?
root_text.dn24:1.14.9: ‘Addhā kho, bhante, evaṁ sante kataṁ hoti uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṁ, no akatan’ti.
root_text.dn24:1.14.10: ‘Evampi kho maṁ tvaṁ, moghapurisa, uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṁ karontaṁ evaṁ vadesi:
root_text.dn24:1.14.11: “na hi pana me, bhante, bhagavā uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṁ karotī”ti.
root_text.dn24:1.14.12: Passa, moghapurisa, yāvañca te idaṁ aparaddhan’ti.
root_text.dn24:1.14.13: Evampi kho, bhaggava, sunakkhatto licchaviputto mayā vuccamāno apakkameva imasmā dhammavinayā, yathā taṁ āpāyiko nerayiko.
root_text.dn24:1.15.1: Ekamidāhaṁ, bhaggava, samayaṁ tattheva vesāliyaṁ viharāmi mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṁ.
root_text.dn24:1.15.2: Tena kho pana samayena acelo pāthikaputto vesāliyaṁ paṭivasati lābhaggappatto ceva yasaggappatto ca vajjigāme.
root_text.dn24:1.15.3: So vesāliyaṁ parisati evaṁ vācaṁ bhāsati:
root_text.dn24:1.15.5: Ñāṇavādo kho pana ñāṇavādena arahati uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṁ dassetuṁ.
root_text.dn24:1.15.6: Samaṇo gotamo upaḍḍhapathaṁ āgaccheyya, ahampi upaḍḍhapathaṁ gaccheyyaṁ.
root_text.dn24:1.15.7: Te tattha ubhopi uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṁ kareyyāma.
root_text.dn24:1.15.8: Ekañce samaṇo gotamo uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṁ karissati, dvāhaṁ karissāmi.
root_text.dn24:1.15.9: Dve ce samaṇo gotamo uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyāni karissati, cattārāhaṁ karissāmi.
root_text.dn24:1.15.10: Cattāri ce samaṇo gotamo uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyāni karissati, aṭṭhāhaṁ karissāmi.
root_text.dn24:1.15.11: Iti yāvatakaṁ yāvatakaṁ samaṇo gotamo uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṁ karissati, taddiguṇaṁ taddiguṇāhaṁ karissāmī’ti.

root_text.dn24:1.16.12: Evaṁ vutte, ahaṁ, bhaggava, sunakkhattaṁ licchaviputtaṁ etadavocaṁ:
root_text.dn24:1.16.13: ‘abhabbo kho, sunakkhatta, acelo pāthikaputto taṁ vācaṁ appahāya taṁ cittaṁ appahāya taṁ diṭṭhiṁ appaṭinissajjitvā mama sammukhībhāvaṁ āgantuṁ.
root_text.dn24:1.16.15: ahaṁ taṁ vācaṁ appahāya taṁ cittaṁ appahāya taṁ diṭṭhiṁ appaṭinissajjitvā samaṇassa gotamassa sammukhībhāvaṁ gaccheyyanti, muddhāpi tassa vipateyyā’ti.
root_text.dn24:1.17.1: ‘Rakkhatetaṁ, bhante, bhagavā vācaṁ, rakkhatetaṁ sugato vācan’ti.
root_text.dn24:1.17.2: ‘Kiṁ pana maṁ tvaṁ, sunakkhatta, evaṁ vadesi—
root_text.dn24:1.17.3: rakkhatetaṁ, bhante, bhagavā vācaṁ, rakkhatetaṁ sugato vācan’ti?
root_text.dn24:1.17.4: ‘Bhagavatā cassa, bhante, esā vācā ekaṁsena odhāritā—
root_text.dn24:1.17.5: abhabbo acelo pāthikaputto taṁ vācaṁ appahāya taṁ cittaṁ appahāya taṁ diṭṭhiṁ appaṭinissajjitvā mama sammukhībhāvaṁ āgantuṁ.
root_text.dn24:1.17.7: ahaṁ taṁ vācaṁ appahāya taṁ cittaṁ appahāya taṁ diṭṭhiṁ appaṭinissajjitvā samaṇassa gotamassa sammukhībhāvaṁ gaccheyyanti, muddhāpi tassa vipateyyāti.
root_text.dn24:1.17.8: Acelo ca, bhante, pāthikaputto virūparūpena bhagavato sammukhībhāvaṁ āgaccheyya, tadassa bhagavato musā’ti.
root_text.dn24:1.18.1: ‘Api nu, sunakkhatta, tathāgato taṁ vācaṁ bhāseyya yā sā vācā dvayagāminī’ti?

root_text.dn24:1.19.1: Atha khvāhaṁ, bhaggava, pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya vesāliṁ piṇḍāya pāvisiṁ.
root_text.dn24:1.19.2: Vesāliyaṁ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto yena acelassa pāthikaputtassa ārāmo tenupasaṅkamiṁ divāvihārāya.
root_text.dn24:1.19.3: Atha kho, bhaggava, sunakkhatto licchaviputto taramānarūpo vesāliṁ pavisitvā yena abhiññātā abhiññātā licchavī tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā abhiññāte abhiññāte licchavī etadavoca:
root_text.dn24:1.19.4: ‘esāvuso, bhagavā vesāliyaṁ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto yena acelassa pāthikaputtassa ārāmo tenupasaṅkami divāvihārāya.
root_text.dn24:1.19.5: Abhikkamathāyasmanto abhikkamathāyasmanto, sādhurūpānaṁ samaṇānaṁ uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṁ bhavissatī’ti.
root_text.dn24:1.19.6: Atha kho, bhaggava, abhiññātānaṁ abhiññātānaṁ licchavīnaṁ etadahosi:
root_text.dn24:1.19.7: ‘sādhurūpānaṁ kira, bho, samaṇānaṁ uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṁ bhavissati;

root_text.dn24:2.6.13: Yannūnāhampi aññataraṁ vanasaṇḍaṁ nissāya āsayaṁ kappeyyaṁ.

root_text.dn24:2.13.4: yatheva te ahaṁ acelaṁ pāthikaputtaṁ ārabbha byākāsiṁ, tatheva taṁ vipākaṁ aññathā vā’ti?
root_text.dn24:2.13.5: ‘Yatheva me, bhante, bhagavā acelaṁ pāthikaputtaṁ ārabbha byākāsi, tatheva taṁ vipākaṁ, no aññathā’ti.

root_text.dn24:2.13.8: ‘Addhā kho, bhante, evaṁ sante kataṁ hoti uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṁ, no akatan’ti.

root_text.dn24:2.13.10: na hi pana me, bhante, bhagavā uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṁ karotīti.
root_text.dn24:2.13.11: Passa, moghapurisa, yāvañca te idaṁ aparaddhan’ti.
root_text.dn24:2.13.12: Evampi kho, bhaggava, sunakkhatto licchaviputto mayā vuccamāno apakkameva imasmā dhammavinayā, yathā taṁ āpāyiko nerayiko.
root_text.dn24:2.14.2: Tañca pajānāmi, tato ca uttaritaraṁ pajānāmi, tañca pajānaṁ na parāmasāmi, aparāmasato ca me paccattaññeva nibbuti viditā, yadabhijānaṁ tathāgato no anayaṁ āpajjati.
root_text.dn24:2.14.3: Santi, bhaggava, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā issarakuttaṁ brahmakuttaṁ ācariyakaṁ aggaññaṁ paññapenti.
root_text.dn24:2.14.5: ‘saccaṁ kira tumhe āyasmanto issarakuttaṁ brahmakuttaṁ ācariyakaṁ aggaññaṁ paññapethā’ti?
root_text.dn24:2.14.6: Te ca me evaṁ puṭṭhā, ‘āmo’ti paṭijānanti.
root_text.dn24:2.14.8: ‘kathaṁvihitakaṁ pana tumhe āyasmanto issarakuttaṁ brahmakuttaṁ ācariyakaṁ aggaññaṁ paññapethā’ti?
root_text.dn24:2.14.9: Te mayā puṭṭhā na sampāyanti, asampāyantā mamaññeva paṭipucchanti.
root_text.dn24:2.14.11: ‘Hoti kho so, āvuso, samayo yaṁ kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhuno accayena ayaṁ loko saṁvaṭṭati.
root_text.dn24:2.14.12: Saṁvaṭṭamāne loke yebhuyyena sattā ābhassarasaṁvattanikā honti.
root_text.dn24:2.14.13: Te tattha honti manomayā pītibhakkhā sayaṁpabhā antalikkhacarā subhaṭṭhāyino ciraṁ dīghamaddhānaṁ tiṭṭhanti.
root_text.dn24:2.15.1: Hoti kho so, āvuso, samayo yaṁ kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhuno accayena ayaṁ loko vivaṭṭati.
root_text.dn24:2.15.3: Atha kho aññataro satto āyukkhayā vā puññakkhayā vā ābhassarakāyā cavitvā suññaṁ brahmavimānaṁ upapajjati.
root_text.dn24:2.15.4: So tattha hoti manomayo pītibhakkho sayampabho antalikkhacaro subhaṭṭhāyī, ciraṁ dīghamaddhānaṁ tiṭṭhati.
root_text.dn24:2.16.1: Tassa tattha ekakassa dīgharattaṁ nivusitattā anabhirati paritassanā uppajjati—
root_text.dn24:2.16.2: aho vata aññepi sattā itthattaṁ āgaccheyyunti.
root_text.dn24:2.16.3: Atha aññepi sattā āyukkhayā vā puññakkhayā vā ābhassarakāyā cavitvā suññaṁ brahmavimānaṁ upapajjanti tassa sattassa sahabyataṁ.
root_text.dn24:2.16.4: Tepi tattha honti manomayā pītibhakkhā sayaṁpabhā antalikkhacarā subhaṭṭhāyino, ciraṁ dīghamaddhānaṁ tiṭṭhanti.
root_text.dn24:2.17.1: Tatrāvuso, yo so satto paṭhamaṁ upapanno, tassa evaṁ hoti—
root_text.dn24:2.17.2: ahamasmi brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānaṁ, mayā ime sattā nimmitā.
root_text.dn24:2.17.5: aho vata aññepi sattā itthattaṁ āgaccheyyunti;
root_text.dn24:2.17.6: iti mama ca manopaṇidhi. Ime ca sattā itthattaṁ āgatāti.
root_text.dn24:2.17.7: Yepi te sattā pacchā upapannā, tesampi evaṁ hoti—
root_text.dn24:2.17.8: ayaṁ kho bhavaṁ brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānaṁ;
root_text.dn24:2.17.11: Imañhi mayaṁ addasāma idha paṭhamaṁ upapannaṁ; mayaṁ panāmha pacchā upapannāti.
root_text.dn24:2.17.12: Tatrāvuso, yo so satto paṭhamaṁ upapanno, so dīghāyukataro ca hoti vaṇṇavantataro ca mahesakkhataro ca.
root_text.dn24:2.17.13: Ye pana te sattā pacchā upapannā, te appāyukatarā ca honti dubbaṇṇatarā ca appesakkhatarā ca.
root_text.dn24:2.17.14: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, āvuso, vijjati, yaṁ aññataro satto tamhā kāyā cavitvā itthattaṁ āgacchati.
root_text.dn24:2.17.15: Itthattaṁ āgato samāno agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati.
root_text.dn24:2.17.16: Agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito samāno ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṁ cetosamādhiṁ phusati, yathāsamāhite citte taṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati; tato paraṁ nānussarati.
root_text.dn24:2.17.18: “yo kho so bhavaṁ brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānaṁ, yena mayaṁ bhotā brahmunā nimmitā. So nicco dhuvo sassato avipariṇāmadhammo sassatisamaṁ tatheva ṭhassati.
root_text.dn24:2.17.19: Ye pana mayaṁ ahumhā tena bhotā brahmunā nimmitā, te mayaṁ aniccā addhuvā appāyukā cavanadhammā itthattaṁ āgatā”ti.
root_text.dn24:2.17.20: Evaṁvihitakaṁ no tumhe āyasmanto issarakuttaṁ brahmakuttaṁ ācariyakaṁ aggaññaṁ paññapethā’ti.
root_text.dn24:2.17.22: ‘evaṁ kho no, āvuso gotama, sutaṁ, yathevāyasmā gotamo āhā’ti.
root_text.dn24:2.17.24: Tañca pajānāmi, tato ca uttaritaraṁ pajānāmi, tañca pajānaṁ na parāmasāmi, aparāmasato ca me paccattaññeva nibbuti viditā. Yadabhijānaṁ tathāgato no anayaṁ āpajjati.
root_text.dn24:2.18.1: Santi, bhaggava, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā khiḍḍāpadosikaṁ ācariyakaṁ aggaññaṁ paññapenti.
root_text.dn24:2.18.3: ‘saccaṁ kira tumhe āyasmanto khiḍḍāpadosikaṁ ācariyakaṁ aggaññaṁ paññapethā’ti?

root_text.dn24:2.18.9: ‘Santāvuso, khiḍḍāpadosikā nāma devā. Te ativelaṁ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannā viharanti. Tesaṁ ativelaṁ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannānaṁ viharataṁ sati sammussati, satiyā sammosā te devā tamhā kāyā cavanti.

root_text.dn24:2.18.11: itthattaṁ āgato samāno agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati,
root_text.dn24:2.18.12: agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito samāno ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṁ cetosamādhiṁ phusati, yathāsamāhite citte taṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati; tato paraṁ nānussarati.

root_text.dn24:2.18.15: niccā dhuvā sassatā avipariṇāmadhammā sassatisamaṁ tatheva ṭhassanti.

root_text.dn24:2.18.17: aniccā addhuvā appāyukā cavanadhammā itthattaṁ āgatā”ti.

root_text.dn24:2.19.3: ‘saccaṁ kira tumhe āyasmanto manopadosikaṁ ācariyakaṁ aggaññaṁ paññapethā’ti?
root_text.dn24:2.19.4: Te ca me evaṁ puṭṭhā ‘āmo’ti paṭijānanti.
root_text.dn24:2.19.6: ‘kathaṁvihitakaṁ pana tumhe āyasmanto manopadosikaṁ ācariyakaṁ aggaññaṁ paññapethā’ti?
root_text.dn24:2.19.7: Te mayā puṭṭhā na sampāyanti, asampāyantā mamaññeva paṭipucchanti.
root_text.dn24:2.19.9: ‘Santāvuso, manopadosikā nāma devā. Te ativelaṁ aññamaññaṁ upanijjhāyanti. Te ativelaṁ aññamaññaṁ upanijjhāyantā aññamaññamhi cittāni padūsenti. Te aññamaññaṁ paduṭṭhacittā kilantakāyā kilantacittā. Te devā tamhā kāyā cavanti.
root_text.dn24:2.19.10: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, āvuso, vijjati, yaṁ aññataro satto tamhā kāyā cavitvā itthattaṁ āgacchati.
root_text.dn24:2.19.11: Itthattaṁ āgato samāno agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati.
root_text.dn24:2.19.12: Agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito samāno ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṁ cetosamādhiṁ phusati, yathāsamāhite citte taṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, tato paraṁ nānussarati.
root_text.dn24:2.19.14: “ye kho te bhonto devā na manopadosikā te nātivelaṁ aññamaññaṁ upanijjhāyanti. Te nātivelaṁ aññamaññaṁ upanijjhāyantā aññamaññamhi cittāni nappadūsenti. Te aññamaññaṁ appaduṭṭhacittā akilantakāyā akilantacittā. Te devā tamhā kāyā na cavanti,
root_text.dn24:2.19.15: niccā dhuvā sassatā avipariṇāmadhammā sassatisamaṁ tatheva ṭhassanti.
root_text.dn24:2.19.16: Ye pana mayaṁ ahumhā manopadosikā, te mayaṁ ativelaṁ aññamaññaṁ upanijjhāyimhā. Te mayaṁ ativelaṁ aññamaññaṁ upanijjhāyantā aññamaññamhi cittāni padūsimhā. Te mayaṁ aññamaññaṁ paduṭṭhacittā kilantakāyā kilantacittā. Evaṁ mayaṁ tamhā kāyā cutā,
root_text.dn24:2.19.17: aniccā addhuvā appāyukā cavanadhammā itthattaṁ āgatā”ti.

root_text.dn24:2.20.3: ‘saccaṁ kira tumhe āyasmanto adhiccasamuppannaṁ ācariyakaṁ aggaññaṁ paññapethā’ti?
root_text.dn24:2.20.4: Te ca me evaṁ puṭṭhā ‘āmo’ti paṭijānanti.
root_text.dn24:2.20.6: ‘kathaṁvihitakaṁ pana tumhe āyasmanto adhiccasamuppannaṁ ācariyakaṁ aggaññaṁ paññapethā’ti?
root_text.dn24:2.20.7: Te mayā puṭṭhā na sampāyanti, asampāyantā mamaññeva paṭipucchanti.
root_text.dn24:2.20.10: Saññuppādā ca pana te devā tamhā kāyā cavanti.
root_text.dn24:2.20.11: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, āvuso, vijjati yaṁ aññataro satto tamhā kāyā cavitvā itthattaṁ āgacchati.
root_text.dn24:2.20.12: Itthattaṁ āgato samāno agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati.
root_text.dn24:2.20.13: Agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito samāno ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṁ cetosamādhiṁ phusati, yathāsamāhite citte taṁ saññuppādaṁ anussarati, tato paraṁ nānussarati’.
root_text.dn24:2.20.17: Ahañhi pubbe nāhosiṁ, somhi etarahi ahutvā santatāya pariṇato’ti.
root_text.dn24:2.20.18: ‘Evaṁvihitakaṁ no tumhe āyasmanto adhiccasamuppannaṁ ācariyakaṁ aggaññaṁ paññapethā’ti?
root_text.dn24:2.20.20: ‘evaṁ kho no, āvuso gotama, sutaṁ yathevāyasmā gotamo āhā’ti.
root_text.dn24:2.20.21: Aggaññañcāhaṁ, bhaggava, pajānāmi tañca pajānāmi, tato ca uttaritaraṁ pajānāmi, tañca pajānaṁ na parāmasāmi, aparāmasato ca me paccattaññeva nibbuti viditā.
root_text.dn24:2.21.1: Evaṁvādiṁ kho maṁ, bhaggava, evamakkhāyiṁ eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā asatā tucchā musā abhūtena abbhācikkhanti:
root_text.dn24:2.21.4: yasmiṁ samaye subhaṁ vimokkhaṁ upasampajja viharati, sabbaṁ tasmiṁ samaye asubhantveva pajānātī’ti.
root_text.dn24:2.21.5: Na kho panāhaṁ, bhaggava, evaṁ vadāmi:
root_text.dn24:2.21.6: ‘yasmiṁ samaye subhaṁ vimokkhaṁ upasampajja viharati, sabbaṁ tasmiṁ samaye asubhantveva pajānātī’ti.
root_text.dn24:2.21.8: ‘yasmiṁ samaye subhaṁ vimokkhaṁ upasampajja viharati, subhantveva tasmiṁ samaye pajānātī’”ti.
root_text.dn24:2.21.9: “Te ca, bhante, viparītā, ye bhagavantaṁ viparītato dahanti bhikkhavo ca.
root_text.dn24:2.21.10: Evaṁpasanno ahaṁ, bhante, bhagavati. Pahoti me bhagavā tathā dhammaṁ desetuṁ, yathā ahaṁ subhaṁ vimokkhaṁ upasampajja vihareyyan”ti.
root_text.dn24:2.21.11: “Dukkaraṁ kho etaṁ, bhaggava, tayā aññadiṭṭhikena aññakhantikena aññarucikena aññatrāyogena aññatrācariyakena subhaṁ vimokkhaṁ upasampajja viharituṁ.
root_text.dn24:2.21.12: Iṅgha tvaṁ, bhaggava, yo ca te ayaṁ mayi pasādo, tameva tvaṁ sādhukamanurakkhā”ti.
root_text.dn24:2.21.13: “Sace taṁ, bhante, mayā dukkaraṁ aññadiṭṭhikena aññakhantikena aññarucikena aññatrāyogena aññatrācariyakena subhaṁ vimokkhaṁ upasampajja viharituṁ.
root_text.dn24:2.21.14: Yo ca me ayaṁ, bhante, bhagavati pasādo, tamevāhaṁ sādhukamanurakkhissāmī”ti.
root_text.dn24:2.21.16: Attamano bhaggavagotto paribbājako bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandīti.

translation_text.dn24:1.1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Mallas, near the Mallian town named Anupiya.
translation_text.dn24:1.1.3: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Anupiya for alms.
translation_text.dn24:1.1.5: “It’s too early to wander for alms in Anupiya.
translation_text.dn24:1.1.6: Why don’t I go to visit the wanderer of the Bhaggava clan in his monastery?”
translation_text.dn24:1.2.2: Then the wanderer of the Bhaggava clan said to the Buddha,
translation_text.dn24:1.2.4: Welcome to the Blessed One, sir!
translation_text.dn24:1.2.5: It’s been a long time since you took the opportunity to come here.
translation_text.dn24:1.2.6: Please, sir, sit down, this seat is ready.”
translation_text.dn24:1.2.7: The Buddha sat on the seat spread out,
translation_text.dn24:1.2.8: while the wanderer of the Bhaggava clan took a low seat, sat to one side,
translation_text.dn24:1.2.10: “Sir, a few days ago Sunakkhatta the Licchavi came to me and said:
translation_text.dn24:1.2.11: ‘Now, Bhaggava, I have disavowed the Buddha.
translation_text.dn24:1.2.12: Now I no longer live dedicated to him.’
translation_text.dn24:1.2.13: Sir, is what Sunakkhatta said true?”
translation_text.dn24:1.3.1: A few days ago Sunakkhatta the Licchavi came to me, bowed, sat down to one side, and said:
translation_text.dn24:1.3.3: Now I shall no longer live dedicated to you.’
translation_text.dn24:1.3.4: When Sunakkhatta said this, I said to him,
translation_text.dn24:1.3.5: ‘But Sunakkhatta, did I ever say to you:
translation_text.dn24:1.3.8: ‘Or did you ever say to me:
translation_text.dn24:1.3.9: “Sir, I shall live dedicated to the Buddha”?’
translation_text.dn24:1.3.11: ‘So it seems that I did not ask you to
translation_text.dn24:1.3.13: nor did you say you would
translation_text.dn24:1.3.15: In that case, you futile man, who are you and what do you want to disavow?
translation_text.dn24:1.3.16: See how far you have strayed!’
translation_text.dn24:1.4.1: ‘But sir, the Buddha never performs any superhuman demonstrations of psychic power for me.’
translation_text.dn24:1.4.2: ‘But Sunakkhatta, did I ever say to you:
translation_text.dn24:1.4.3: “Come, live dedicated to me and I will perform a superhuman demonstration of psychic power for you”?’
translation_text.dn24:1.4.5: ‘Or did you ever say to me:
translation_text.dn24:1.4.6: “Sir, I shall live dedicated to the Buddha, and the Buddha will perform a superhuman demonstration of psychic power for me”?’
translation_text.dn24:1.4.8: ‘So it seems that I did not ask this of you, and you did not require it of me.
translation_text.dn24:1.4.12: In that case, you futile man, who are you and what do you want to disavow?
translation_text.dn24:1.4.14: Whether or not there is a demonstration of psychic power, does my teaching lead someone who practices it to the goal of the complete ending of suffering?’
translation_text.dn24:1.4.16: ‘So it seems that whether or not there is a demonstration of psychic power, my teaching leads someone who practices it to the goal of the complete ending of suffering.
translation_text.dn24:1.4.17: In that case, what is the point of superhuman demonstrations of psychic power?
translation_text.dn24:1.4.18: See how far you have strayed, you silly man!’
translation_text.dn24:1.5.1: ‘But sir, the Buddha never describes the origin of the world to me.’
translation_text.dn24:1.5.2: ‘But Sunakkhatta, did I ever say to you:
translation_text.dn24:1.5.3: “Come, live dedicated to me and I will describe the origin of the world to you”?’
translation_text.dn24:1.5.5: ‘Or did you ever say to me:
translation_text.dn24:1.5.6: “Sir, I shall live dedicated to the Buddha, and the Buddha will describe the origin of the world to me”?’
translation_text.dn24:1.5.8: ‘So it seems that I did not ask this of you, and you did not require it of me.
translation_text.dn24:1.5.12: In that case, you futile man, who are you and what do you want to disavow?
translation_text.dn24:1.5.14: Whether or not the origin of the world is described, does my teaching lead someone who practices it to the goal of the complete ending of suffering?’
translation_text.dn24:1.5.16: ‘So it seems that whether or not the origin of the world is described, my teaching leads someone who practices it to the goal of the complete ending of suffering.
translation_text.dn24:1.5.17: In that case, what is the point of describing the origin of the world?
translation_text.dn24:1.5.18: See how far you have strayed, you silly man!
translation_text.dn24:1.6.1: In many ways, Sunakkhatta, you have praised me like this in the Vajjian capital:
translation_text.dn24:1.6.2: “That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.”
translation_text.dn24:1.6.4: In many ways you have praised the teaching like this in the Vajjian capital:
translation_text.dn24:1.6.5: “The teaching is well explained by the Buddha—apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.”
translation_text.dn24:1.6.7: In many ways you have praised the Saṅgha like this in the Vajjian capital:
translation_text.dn24:1.6.8: “The Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples is practicing the way that’s good, direct, systematic, and proper. It consists of the four pairs, the eight individual persons. This is the Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples that is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.”
translation_text.dn24:1.6.10: I declare this to you, Sunakkhatta, I announce this to you!
translation_text.dn24:1.6.11: There will be those who say that Sunakkhatta was unable to lead the spiritual life under the ascetic Gotama. That’s why he resigned the training and returned to a lesser life.
translation_text.dn24:1.6.13: Though I spoke to Sunakkhatta like this, he still left this teaching and training, like someone on the highway to hell.
translation_text.dn24:1.7.1: Bhaggava, this one time I was staying in the land of the Kurus where they have a town named Uttarakā.
translation_text.dn24:1.7.2: Then I robed up in the morning and, taking my bowl and robe, entered Uttarakā for alms with Sunakkhatta the Licchavi as my second monk.
translation_text.dn24:1.7.3: Now at that time a naked ascetic who was an aristocrat of Kuru had taken a vow to behave like a dog. When food is tossed on the ground, he gets down on all fours, eating and devouring it just with his mouth.
translation_text.dn24:1.7.7: Then, knowing Sunakkhatta’s train of thought, I said to him,
translation_text.dn24:1.7.8: ‘Don’t you claim to be an ascetic who follows the Sakyan, you silly man?’
translation_text.dn24:1.7.9: ‘But why does the Buddha say this to me?’
translation_text.dn24:1.7.11: ‘When you saw that naked ascetic of Kuru, didn’t you think,
translation_text.dn24:1.7.14: But sir, are you jealous of the perfected ones?’
translation_text.dn24:1.7.15: ‘I’m not jealous of the perfected ones, you silly man.
translation_text.dn24:1.7.16: Rather, you should give up this harmful misconception that has arisen in you.
translation_text.dn24:1.7.17: Don’t create lasting harm and suffering for yourself!
translation_text.dn24:1.7.18: That naked ascetic the aristocrat of Kuru, who you imagine to be a holy man, will die of flatulence in seven days.
translation_text.dn24:1.7.19: And when he dies, he’ll be reborn in the very lowest rank of titans, named the Kālakañjas.
translation_text.dn24:1.7.20: And they’ll throw him in the charnel ground on a clump of vetiver.
translation_text.dn24:1.7.21: If you wish, Sunakkhatta, go to the aristocrat of Kuru and ask him
translation_text.dn24:1.7.22: whether he knows his own destiny.
translation_text.dn24:1.7.23: It’s possible that he will answer:
translation_text.dn24:1.7.24: “Reverend Sunakkhatta, I know my own destiny.
translation_text.dn24:1.7.25: I’ve been reborn in the very lowest rank of titans, named the Kālakañjas.”’
translation_text.dn24:1.8.1: So, Bhaggava, Sunakkhatta went to see the aristocrat of Kuru and said to him,
translation_text.dn24:1.8.2: ‘Reverend aristocrat of Kuru, the ascetic Gotama has declared
translation_text.dn24:1.8.3: that you will die of flatulence in seven days.
translation_text.dn24:1.8.4: And when you die, you’ll be reborn in the very lowest rank of titans, named the Kālakañjas.
translation_text.dn24:1.8.5: And when you die, they’ll throw you in the charnel ground on a clump of vetiver.
translation_text.dn24:1.8.6: But by eating just a little food and drinking just a little water,
translation_text.dn24:1.8.7: you’ll prove what the ascetic Gotama says to be false.’
translation_text.dn24:1.8.8: Then Sunakkhatta counted up the days until the seventh day, as happens when you have no faith in the Realized One.
translation_text.dn24:1.8.9: But on the seventh day, the naked ascetic who was an aristocrat of Kuru died of flatulence.
translation_text.dn24:1.8.10: And when he passed away, he was reborn in the very lowest rank of titans, named the Kālakañjas.
translation_text.dn24:1.8.11: And when he passed away, they threw him in the charnel ground on a clump of vetiver.
translation_text.dn24:1.9.1: Sunakkhatta the Licchavi heard about this.
translation_text.dn24:1.9.3: So he went to see the aristocrat of Kuru in the charnel ground on the clump of vetiver. There he struck him with his fist three times,
translation_text.dn24:1.9.4: ‘Reverend aristocrat of Kuru, do you know your destiny?’

translation_text.dn24:1.10.1: Then Sunakkhatta came to me, bowed, and sat down to one side. I said to him,
translation_text.dn24:1.10.3: Did the prediction I made about the aristocrat of Kuru turn out to be correct, or not?’

translation_text.dn24:1.11.1: This one time, Bhaggava, I was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.

translation_text.dn24:1.11.4: ‘As long as I live, I will be a naked ascetic, not wearing clothes. As long as I live, I will be chaste, not having sex. As long as I live, I will consume only meat and beer, not eating rice and porridge.
translation_text.dn24:1.11.5: And I will not go past the following shrines near Vesālī: the Udena Shrine to the east, the Gotamaka to the south, the Seven Maidens to the west, and the Many Sons to the north.’
translation_text.dn24:1.11.6: And it was due to undertaking these seven vows that he had reached the peak of material things and fame.

translation_text.dn24:1.15.8: If he performs one demonstration of psychic power, I’ll perform two.
translation_text.dn24:1.15.9: If he performs two, I’ll perform four.

translation_text.dn24:1.15.11: However many demonstrations of psychic power the ascetic Gotama performs, I’ll perform double.’

translation_text.dn24:2.10.4: and carcasses tossed in the cemetery,
translation_text.dn24:2.10.5: thriving in the great, empty wood,
translation_text.dn24:2.10.6: the jackal presumed “I’m the king of the beasts!”
translation_text.dn24:2.10.7: But he actually only managed to yelp,
translation_text.dn24:2.10.8: and what’s a sad jackal’s squeal to the roar of a lion?
translation_text.dn24:2.10.9: In the same way, reverend, while living off the leavings of the Holy One, enjoying the leftovers of the Holy One, you presume to attack the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!
translation_text.dn24:2.10.10: Who are the pathetic Pāṭikaputtas to attack the Realized Ones, the perfected ones, the fully awakened Buddhas?’
translation_text.dn24:2.11.1: When Jāliya couldn’t get Pāṭikaputta to shift from his seat even with this simile,
translation_text.dn24:2.11.2: he returned to the assembly and said,
translation_text.dn24:2.11.3: ‘Pāṭikaputta has lost, worthies. He says “I’m coming, good sirs, I’m coming!” But wriggle as he might, he can’t get up from his seat.’
translation_text.dn24:2.12.1: When he said this, I said to the assembly,
translation_text.dn24:2.12.2: ‘The naked ascetic Pāṭikaputta is not capable of meeting me face to face, unless he gives up that statement and that intention, and lets go of that view.
translation_text.dn24:2.12.4: meet me face to face without giving up those things, his head may explode.
translation_text.dn24:2.12.5: The good Licchavis might even think,
translation_text.dn24:2.12.6: “Let’s bind Pāṭikaputta with straps and drag him with a pair of oxen!” But either the straps will break or Pāṭikaputta will.
translation_text.dn24:2.12.7: Pāṭikaputta is not capable of meeting me face to face, otherwise
translation_text.dn24:2.13.1: Then, Bhaggava, I educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired that assembly with a Dhamma talk. I released that assembly from the great bondage, and lifted 84,000 beings from the great swamp. Next I entered upon the fire element, rose into the air to the height of seven palm trees, and created a flame another seven palm trees high, blazing and smoking. Finally I landed at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
translation_text.dn24:2.13.2: Then Sunakkhatta came to me, bowed, and sat down to one side. I said to him,
translation_text.dn24:2.13.4: Did the declaration I made about Pāṭikaputta turn out to be correct, or not?’
translation_text.dn24:2.13.7: If that is so, has a superhuman demonstration of psychic power been performed or not?’
translation_text.dn24:2.13.8: ‘Clearly, sir, a superhuman demonstration of psychic power has been performed.’
translation_text.dn24:2.13.9: ‘Though I perform such a superhuman demonstration of psychic power you say this:
translation_text.dn24:2.13.10: “But sir, the Buddha never performs any superhuman demonstrations of psychic power for me.”
translation_text.dn24:2.13.11: See how far you have strayed!’
translation_text.dn24:2.13.12: Though I spoke to Sunakkhatta like this, he still left this teaching and training, like someone on the highway to hell.
translation_text.dn24:2.14.0: 6. On Describing the Origin of the World
translation_text.dn24:2.14.1: Bhaggava, I understand the origin of the world.
translation_text.dn24:2.14.2: I understand this, and what goes beyond it. Yet since I do not misapprehend that understanding, I have realized quenching within myself. Directly knowing this, the Realized One does not come to ruin.
translation_text.dn24:2.14.3: There are some ascetics and brahmins who describe the origin of the world in their tradition as created by the God Almighty, by the Divinity.
translation_text.dn24:2.14.4: I go up to them and say,
translation_text.dn24:2.14.5: ‘Is it really true that this is the venerables’ view?’
translation_text.dn24:2.14.8: ‘But how do you describe in your tradition that the origin of the world came about as created by the God Almighty, by the Divinity?’
translation_text.dn24:2.14.9: But they are stumped by my question, and they even question me in return.
translation_text.dn24:2.14.11: ‘There comes a time when, reverends, after a very long period has passed, this cosmos contracts.
translation_text.dn24:2.14.12: As the cosmos contracts, sentient beings are mostly headed for the realm of streaming radiance.
translation_text.dn24:2.14.13: There they are mind-made, feeding on rapture, self-luminous, wandering in midair, steadily glorious, and they remain like that for a very long time.
translation_text.dn24:2.15.1: There comes a time when, after a very long period has passed, this cosmos expands.
translation_text.dn24:2.15.2: As it expands an empty mansion of divinity appears.
translation_text.dn24:2.15.3: Then a certain sentient being—due to the running out of their lifespan or merit—passes away from that host of radiant deities and is reborn in that empty mansion of divinity.
translation_text.dn24:2.15.4: There they are mind-made, feeding on rapture, self-luminous, wandering in midair, steadily glorious, and they remain like that for a very long time.
translation_text.dn24:2.16.1: But after staying there all alone for a long time, they become dissatisfied and anxious,
translation_text.dn24:2.16.2: “Oh, if only other beings would come to this place.”
translation_text.dn24:2.16.3: Then other sentient beings—due to the running out of their lifespan or merit—pass away from that host of radiant deities and are reborn in that mansion of divinity in company with that being.
translation_text.dn24:2.16.4: There they too are mind-made, feeding on rapture, self-luminous, wandering in midair, steadily glorious, and they remain like that for a very long time.
translation_text.dn24:2.17.1: Now, the being who was reborn there first thinks,
translation_text.dn24:2.17.2: “I am the Divinity, the Great Divinity, the Vanquisher, the Unvanquished, the Universal Seer, the Wielder of Power,  God Almighty, the Maker, the Creator, the First, the Begetter, the Controller, the Father of those who have been born and those yet to be born. And these beings were created by me.
translation_text.dn24:2.17.5: ‘Oh, if only other beings would come to this place.’
translation_text.dn24:2.17.6: Such was my heart’s wish, and then these creatures came to this place.”
translation_text.dn24:2.17.7: And the beings who were reborn there later also think,
translation_text.dn24:2.17.8: “This must be the Divinity, the Great Divinity, the Vanquisher, the Unvanquished, the Universal Seer, the Wielder of Power, God Almighty, the Maker, the Creator, the First, the Begetter, the Controller, the Father of those who have been born and those yet to be born.
translation_text.dn24:2.17.9: And we were created by him.
translation_text.dn24:2.17.11: Because we see that he was reborn here first, and we arrived later.”
translation_text.dn24:2.17.12: And the being who was reborn first is more long-lived, beautiful, and illustrious than those who arrived later.
translation_text.dn24:2.17.14: It’s possible that one of those beings passes away from that host and is reborn in this place.
translation_text.dn24:2.17.15: Having done so, they go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.dn24:2.17.16: By dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind, they experience an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they recollect that past life, but no further.
translation_text.dn24:2.17.18: “He who is the Divinity—the Great Divinity, the Vanquisher, the Unvanquished, the Universal Seer, the Wielder of Power, God Almighty, the Maker, the Creator, the First, the Begetter, the Controller, the Father of those who have been born and those yet to be born—by he we were created. He is permanent, everlasting, eternal, imperishable, remaining the same for all eternity.
translation_text.dn24:2.17.19: We who were created by that Divinity are impermanent, not lasting, short-lived, liable to pass away, and have come to this place.”
translation_text.dn24:2.17.20: Is this how you describe in your tradition that the origin of the world came about as created by the God Almighty, by the Divinity?’
translation_text.dn24:2.17.22: ‘That is what we have heard, Reverend Gotama, just as you say.’
translation_text.dn24:2.17.23: Bhaggava, I understand the origin of the world.
translation_text.dn24:2.17.24: I understand this, and what goes beyond it. Yet since I do not misapprehend that understanding, I have realized quenching within myself. Directly knowing this, the Realized One does not come to ruin.
translation_text.dn24:2.18.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who describe the origin of the world in their tradition as due to those depraved by play.
translation_text.dn24:2.18.2: I go up to them and say,
translation_text.dn24:2.18.3: ‘Is it really true that this is the venerables’ view?’
translation_text.dn24:2.18.6: ‘But how do you describe in your tradition that the origin of the world came about due to those depraved by play?’
translation_text.dn24:2.18.7: But they are stumped by my question, and they even question me in return.
translation_text.dn24:2.18.9: ‘Reverends, there are gods named “depraved by play”. They spend too much time laughing, playing, and making merry. And in doing so, they lose their mindfulness, and they pass away from that host of gods.
translation_text.dn24:2.18.10: It’s possible that one of those beings passes away from that host and is reborn in this place.
translation_text.dn24:2.18.11: Having done so, they go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.dn24:2.18.12: By dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind, they experience an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they recollect that past life, but no further.
translation_text.dn24:2.18.14: “The gods not depraved by play don’t spend too much time laughing, playing, and making merry. So they don’t lose their mindfulness, and don’t pass away from that host of gods.
translation_text.dn24:2.18.15: They are permanent, everlasting, eternal, imperishable, remaining the same for all eternity.
translation_text.dn24:2.18.16: But we who were depraved by play spent too much time laughing, playing, and making merry. In doing so, we lost our mindfulness, and passed away from that host of gods.
translation_text.dn24:2.18.17: We are impermanent, not lasting, short-lived, liable to pass away, and have come to this place.”
translation_text.dn24:2.18.18: Is this how you describe in your tradition that the origin of the world came about due to those depraved by play?’
translation_text.dn24:2.18.20: ‘That is what we have heard, Reverend Gotama, just as you say.’
translation_text.dn24:2.18.21: Bhaggava, I understand the origin of the world.
translation_text.dn24:2.18.22: Directly knowing this, the Realized One does not come to ruin.

translation_text.dn24:2.19.2: I go up to them and say,
translation_text.dn24:2.19.3: ‘Is it really true that this is the venerables’ view?’
translation_text.dn24:2.19.6: ‘But how do you describe in your tradition that the origin of the world came about due to those who are malevolent?’
translation_text.dn24:2.19.7: But they are stumped by my question, and they even question me in return.
translation_text.dn24:2.19.9: ‘Reverends, there are gods named “malevolent”. They spend too much time gazing at each other, so they grow angry with each other, and their bodies and minds get tired. They pass away from that host of gods.
translation_text.dn24:2.19.10: It’s possible that one of those beings passes away from that host and is reborn in this place.
translation_text.dn24:2.19.11: Having done so, they go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.dn24:2.19.12: By dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind, they experience an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they recollect that past life, but no further.
translation_text.dn24:2.19.14: “The gods who are not malevolent don’t spend too much time gazing at each other, so they don’t grow angry with each other, their bodies and minds don’t get tired, and they don’t pass away from that host of gods.
translation_text.dn24:2.19.15: They are permanent, everlasting, eternal, imperishable, remaining the same for all eternity.
translation_text.dn24:2.19.16: But we who were malevolent spent too much time gazing at each other, so our minds grew angry with each other, our bodies and minds got tired, and we passed away from that host of gods.
translation_text.dn24:2.19.17: We are impermanent, not lasting, short-lived, liable to pass away, and have come to this place.”
translation_text.dn24:2.19.18: Is this how you describe in your tradition that the origin of the world came about due to those who are malevolent?’
translation_text.dn24:2.19.20: ‘That is what we have heard, Reverend Gotama, just as you say.’
translation_text.dn24:2.19.21: Bhaggava, I understand the origin of the world.
translation_text.dn24:2.19.22: Directly knowing this, the Realized One does not come to ruin.
translation_text.dn24:2.20.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who describe the origin of the world in their tradition as having arisen as an anomaly.
translation_text.dn24:2.20.2: I go up to them and say,
translation_text.dn24:2.20.3: ‘Is it really true that this is the venerables’ view?’
translation_text.dn24:2.20.6: ‘But how do you describe in your tradition that the origin of the world came about anomalously?’
translation_text.dn24:2.20.7: But they are stumped by my question, and they even question me in return.
translation_text.dn24:2.20.10: When perception arises they pass away from that host of gods.
translation_text.dn24:2.20.11: It’s possible that one of those beings passes away from that host and is reborn in this place.
translation_text.dn24:2.20.12: Having done so, they go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.dn24:2.20.13: By dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind, they experience an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they recollect the arising of perception, but no further.
translation_text.dn24:2.20.15: “The self and the cosmos arose anomalously.
translation_text.dn24:2.20.17: Because formerly I didn’t exist, whereas now, having not existed, I’ve transformed into the state of existing.”
translation_text.dn24:2.20.18: Is this how you describe in your tradition that the origin of the world came about anomalously?’
translation_text.dn24:2.20.20: ‘That is what we have heard, Reverend Gotama, just as you say.’
translation_text.dn24:2.20.21: I understand this, and what goes beyond it. Yet since I do not misapprehend that understanding, I have realized quenching within myself. Directly knowing this, the Realized One does not come to ruin.
translation_text.dn24:2.21.1: Though I state and assert this, certain ascetics and brahmins misrepresent me with the incorrect, hollow, false, untruthful claim:
translation_text.dn24:2.21.2: ‘The ascetic Gotama has a distorted perspective, and so have his monks.
translation_text.dn24:2.21.4: “When one enters and remains in the liberation of the beautiful, at that time one only perceives what is ugly.”’
translation_text.dn24:2.21.8: ‘When one enters and remains in the liberation of the beautiful, at that time one only perceives what is beautiful.’”
translation_text.dn24:2.21.9: “They are the ones with a distorted perspective, sir, who regard the Buddha and the mendicants in this way.
translation_text.dn24:2.21.10: Sir, I am quite confident that the Buddha is capable of teaching me so that I can enter and remain in the liberation on the beautiful.”
translation_text.dn24:2.21.11: “It’s hard for you to enter and remain in the liberation on the beautiful, since you have a different view, creed, and belief, unless you dedicate yourself to practice with the guidance of tradition.
translation_text.dn24:2.21.12: Come now, Bhaggava, carefully preserve the confidence that you have in me.”
translation_text.dn24:2.21.13: “If it’s hard for me to enter and remain in the liberation on the beautiful, since I have a different view, creed, and belief, unless I dedicate myself to practice with the guidance of tradition,
translation_text.dn24:2.21.14: I shall carefully preserve the confidence that I have in the Buddha.”
translation_text.dn24:2.21.15: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.dn24:2.21.16: Satisfied, the wanderer of the Bhaggava clan approved what the Buddha said.
